explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro) - The target uses this macro to obtain 'impl'. A macro expansion can itself contain for-loops or introduce loop-like control; its definition must be inspected to ensure no for-statement is hidden in the target function.

OS_impl_module_table (object) - The macro likely indexes or iterates over this table. Its definition/structure may be referenced in the macro expansion and could reveal loop use or side-effects relevant to MISRA loop clauses.

OS_impl_module_internal_record_t (type) - Needed to inspect the layout and any embedded inline functions, macros, or accessor operations associated with the record that could contain for-loops or modify loop counters.

dl_handle (member of OS_impl_module_internal_record_t) - This member is passed to OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl; its type or accessor macros could hide loops or side-effects, so inspect its declaration.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (function) - The static call graph shows this is a callee related to object-table lookups and may be invoked by the macro. Its implementation must be checked for any for-loops (or modifications of loop counters/objects) that would affect MISRA compliance of the target.

OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl (function) - Directly called by the target. Even though the target has no explicit for-loop, any for-loops inside this callee or functions it calls could be executed in the target's dynamic behavior; inspect its code for for-loops and ensure they are well‑formed per MISRA.

OS_object_token_t (type) - The token is dereferenced in the call to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (via *token). The token type or any associated accessors/macros could contain loop logic; include its definition to rule out hidden for-loops or side-effects.

cpuaddr (typedef) - The SymbolAddress pointer type; include its definition in case any address-related macros or inline functions are used that may contain for-loops or side-effects.

These symbols collectively cover macro expansions, called functions, and the data types/objects accessed by the target function so that any hidden or invoked for-loops can be found and checked against the MISRA 'for loop shall be well-formed' rule.
